own.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: used to emphasize that something belongs to or is connected with a particular person or thing and not any other
own.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: Every dance has its own rhythm.
The yacht was intended for the King’s own personal use.
His face was only a few inches from her own.
One day I want to have a horse of my very own.
She just wanted a place to call her own.
something to call your own/which you can call your own
We have problems of our own.
I’d like to have a place of my own  (=my own home).
own.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: used to emphasize that someone did or made something without the help or involvement of anyone else
own.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: She makes a lot of her own clothes.
We encourage students to develop their own ideas.
It’s your own fault for leaving the window open.
You say my own, her own, their own etc
The town has its own station
The town has an own station
of my own, of her own, of their own etc
I want to have a room of my own
Each house has a garden of its own
own.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: to have something which belongs to you, especially because you have bought it, been given it etc and it is legally yours
own.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: The building is owned by the local council.
You need to get permission from the farmer who owns the land.
Many more people now own their own homes.
the cost of owning a car
own.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: to admit that something is true
own.translation[1].definitions[1].exampl: I own that I judged her harshly at first.
I must own to a feeling of anxiety.
own.translation[1].definitions[2].defini: to defeat someone very easily or by a large amount
Own is not used in the progressive You say
own.translation[1].note_box[1].sections[: own
if you own something, it legally belongs to you
They live in a flat but they don’t own it.
The land is owned by farmers.
a privately owned plane
have
to own something – used when focussing on the fact that someone has the use of something, rather than the fact that they legally own it
How many students have a cell phone?
I wish I had a sports car.
possess
to own something
It is illegal to possess a firearm in Britain.
I don’t even possess a smart suit!
belong to somebody/something
if something belongs to you, you own it
The ring belonged to my grandmother.
to own shares in a company
One man holds a third of the company’s shares.
be the property of somebody/something
to be owned by someone – written on signs, labels etc
This camera is the property of the BBC.
own.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: to have or possess something that is legally yours
own.translation[2].definitions[0].exampl: He still owns shares in the company.
The company is owned by a foreign consortium.
